body: BACK in 1957, Copp's Guide to New York City told tourists: ''You are visiting the World's Most Wonderful City,'' then went on: ''The question in and around New York is not 'What has it to offer?' The question is always: 'What do I want?' '' Ditto New York City on the brink of 2007, but the details have changed dramatically. Even though it would be
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | 1957; Time Warp?Try These Places

body: Correction Appended As Debbie Phillip began to speak during a recent interview, her son Devon, 19, zipped up his hooded sweatshirt, completely covering his face and ears. He soon pretended to be asleep, stretching out and making snoring noises. But his antics did not fool Justin, the youngest brother in the family. He did not want to hear the story
title: NEEDIEST CASES; Child's Disease Strains the Finances of a Canarsie Family

body: SOME of the most arresting and otherworldly photographs of New York are those turn-of-the-century black-and-white pictures of people skating on the lake in Central Park: the women in bustled skirts, the men in bowlers and the lonely outpost of the Dakota in the background. That was back when we had winter. Anyone trying to skate in New York these
title: MY NEW YORK; Skating on a Gershwin Set, Whatever the Tune

body: A week after a hard foul sparked a melee involving players and spectators at a boys basketball game at Paul Robeson High School in Brooklyn, the coach of the visiting team, Thomas Jefferson High School, said he and his players were still recovering from their wounds. ''I have one kid who's missing a tooth,'' said Lawrence Pollard, the Jefferson
title: BASKETBALL; Officials at Two High Schools Say P.S.A.L. Ruling Is Too Harsh

body: SCHOENBRUN--Florence (nee Brown), 76, died December 21, 2006. Beloved mother of Roberta Elins Dinkes and son-in-law Steven R. Dinkes. Aunt of Alan and Jan Brown and the late Gerald Jacobson. Great-aunt of Steven Brown and Scott Jacobson. Daughter of the late Harry and Sarah Brown. Sister of the late Milton Brown and Sylvia Gargiulo. Loved her
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHOENBRUN, FLORENCE (NEE BROWN)

body: The last New York City mechanical parking meter -- an emblem of street life, object of driver frustration and source of fascination for children since 1951 -- was withdrawn from service yesterday. The demise of the mechanical meter was painless but not swift. Since 1995, when the city began using battery-powered digital meters and quickly found
title: When Time Runs Out for the Meter, Not the Car

body: Scruffy but resilient, Coney Island has been a haven for people like Vincent Garcia. For nearly two decades, Mr. Garcia, a stocky, tattooed ex-convict known as Cuba, has lived in a tattered tan trailer in a parking lot on Stillwell Avenue near the Boardwalk. He began staying there while working as a security guard at the lot, he says, after losing
title: CONEY ISLAND JOURNAL; No Place for Biker's Trailer As Seascape Loses Its Grit

author: Ben Gibberd's book ''New York Waters: Profiles From the Edge,'' with photographs by Randy Duchaine, will be published in May by Globe Pequot Press.
body: Susan Harder, a former photo gallery owner who has lived for decades in the same walk-up apartment on East 10th Street, is the first to acknowledge that she is all of 57 years old, but she emanates an air of schoolgirlish mischief. Her blue eyes twinkle, her blond ponytail bounces, and she punctuates her sentences with what can only be described as
title: Tilting At Lampposts

body: Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. More than 25 buildings, from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. title: Spare Times

body: Stephon Marbury's campaign to make athletic shoes affordable will reach a new level tomorrow afternoon. He is giving away 3,000 pairs of his Starbury One shoes, one for every high school varsity boys player in New York City. Marbury launched the shoes, which sell for $14.98 a pair, last summer, in partnership with the Steve and Barry's chain of
title: If the Shoe Fits, Marbury Decides To Give It Away

body: Thor Equities, a developer that has proposed building a $1.5 billion, year-round entertainment and amusement district in Coney Island, bought the Astroland amusement park yesterday for about $30 million. The 3.1-acre parcel along West 10th Street, from Surf Avenue to the Boardwalk, is home to 35 rides and amusements, including the 270-foot Astro
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Developer Buys Amusement Park

body: Fifteen years ago, Arthur Nash made one of his first purchases of gangland memorabilia when a dealer in rare photographs showed him what he said was the first published picture of the gangster Arnold Rothstein. Before long, Mr. Nash, who was 19 at the time, was searching for photographs of other notorious figures, like Al Capone, Machine Gun Jack
title: In This Rogues' Gallery, Photographs Are Just the Start

body: When they were growing up in Brooklyn, Kevin Shenderov and his older brother, Eugene, would sit on the couch and listen raptly as their father explained in simple yet fascinating terms how the television they were watching worked, or how electricity powered the light bulb that illuminated the room. ''He always made science pretty accessible to
title: 2 Rhodes Scholars Multiply a Family's Bragging Rights

body: UNCHECKED for decades, decay has left Coney Island a motley jumble of vacant lots, forbidding bodegas and shabby, if lovable, amusements. But change is on its way to this scruffy slice of south Brooklyn seafront; the signs are everywhere. KeySpan Park, a handsome minor league baseball stadium, has drawn steady crowds since it opened in 2001.
title: LIVING IN/Coney Island, Brooklyn; Safety Belts On? Renewal Has Its Hazards

body: Nabila Nazli was standing at a window, dangling her newborn above the sidewalk about 20 feet below. Flames were tearing through her second-story apartment in Brooklyn yesterday morning, and she was screaming for help. Two men had raced to her aid, but they could not get into the wood-frame building. Thinking fast, they stretched out a quilt as a
title: Home Afire, Mother Saves 4 and Stays With 5th

body: The builders of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge probably saved someone's life yesterday. They needed a place to dump all the displaced dirt from its construction, and ended up creating a new hunk of land that jutted out of Brooklyn into Coney Island Creek like a hitchhiker's thumb. In 1962, that land became part of a city park. Yesterday, it became an
title: Pilot Stops Short of New Jersey, in Brooklyn Park

body: A woman who leapt in front of a subway Monday, apparently out of remorse over smothering her son, said ''demons overtook her'' when she pressed a pillow to the boy's face and held it there until he became still, the police said yesterday. The woman, identified by relatives as Sadier Jean Noel, 27, said her son, Knil Jean Noel, 9, was despondent
title: Mother Who Leapt to Tracks Had Killed Son, Police Say

body: Two police officers helped residents, including a 93-year-old woman, leave a burning apartment building in Bensonhurst yesterday, the police said. The officers responded to a report of a fire just before 8 a.m. at a six-story building at 8747 Bay Parkway. The Fire Department said the blaze, confined to an apartment on the sixth floor, was brought
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officers Help Residents Flee Fire

body: A woman jumped in front of a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday, just before her son was found dead in their Crown Heights apartment on his birthday, the police said. The boy was 9 years old. The woman, who jumped onto the tracks at Surf Avenue and West Eighth Street, in Coney Island, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center. She lost two fingers, the
title: Mother of Boy Found Dead Leaps to Tracks

body: A Brooklyn woman was killed and two other people were injured Saturday night on the Belt Parkway when their car struck a guardrail and rolled over, the police said yesterday. Marina Kapelevich, 24, of West 12th Street was ejected from the back seat in the accident, which occurred in the eastbound lanes of the parkway at the 17th Avenue pedestrian
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed In Accident

body: STRICTLY speaking, Faisal Khan, an assistant district attorney in Queens and a London-born son of immigrants originally from Agra, India, was reared in a culture in which love-matches are not left to serendipity. Marriages are arranged. But while Mr. Khan, 32, considered himself to be a good Muslim, he was an American, too, and he wanted to pick a
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Sanam Hafeez and Faisal Khan

body: IT took no small amount of courage to walk into one of the great Brooklyn pizzerias with a Domino's Brooklyn Style Pizza in our hands. ''Get that thing out of here,'' was the first thing Totonno's owner, Louise Ciminieri, said when she saw the Domino's box. Once we explained that we were on a mission to determine exactly what constituted a Brooklyn
title: 'Brooklyn Style Pizza' Meets the Real Deal

body: It was a brisk Saturday morning at the Columbia University boathouse, near West 218th Street in Upper Manhattan, and Canada geese soared past the Henry Hudson Bridge. Just beyond Spuyten Duyvil a tall freighter moved slowly on the horizon, and on a pier on the Harlem River, Marie Lorenz was preparing to embark on the latest chapter of her unusual
title: She Likes to Show Off New York From the Waterline

body: A man was shot and killed by one of three men attempting to rob a Brooklyn deli last night, the police said. The men fled from the store, the Mini-Mart Deli on Avenue R in Sheepshead Bay. The victim, an employee of the deli whom the police did not identify, was taken to Coney Island Hospital about 9 p.m. and pronounced dead. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Employee Fatally Shot At Deli

body: Harking back to an anti-jaywalking slogan that New York City began in 1957 and used for decades -- ''Cross at the Green, Not in Between'' -- city officials unveiled their newest tool yesterday in the effort to improve pedestrian safety: crosswalk signals that count down the seconds before the light changes. The signals will be used at five
title: Too Slow in the Crosswalk? Automatic Timers Will Tell You

body: FOR years, Charley Wininger, a Gestalt psychotherapist and dating coach in Brooklyn, had wined and dined serious, intellectual women. A hippie who recalls being gassed while protesting the Vietnam War, he has always been passionate about politics and philosophy. He has also been passionate about relationships, pontificating about them on talk shows
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Shelley Yeffet and Charley Wininger

body: Heather Woodbury's mother was reared in Flatbush, Brooklyn, where, she explained, ''you can't really have grown up and not have had the Dodgers be part of your life.'' A playwright and performer, Ms. Woodbury remains, at best, a casual spectator. (''If I was really going to get serious, I would probably root for the Red Sox, because they're
title: Where Fans Were Called Out Looking

body: JANOFSKY - Rachel. Be loved wife of the late Albert, loving mother of Dr. Elliott and Betty Janofsky and Sally and Michael Hipscher, devoted grandmother of Karen, Jenny, Steven, Joel, and Lorraine, and adored greatgrandmother of Emma Rose and Daniel. A strong and gracious woman, remembered for her great will to survive, her strength of character
title: Paid Notice: Deaths JANOFSKY, RACHEL

body: PEOPLE-WATCHING is to New York City what vista-gazing is to the Grand Canyon: You haven't really been if you haven't done it. But you don't just watch people here, you watch their poodles and pugs, too. And you don't just watch people, you eavesdrop on them or even follow them (briefly, please). There are no ethical qualms: People here know that
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: PEOPLE-WATCHING; Here's Looking at You

body: An out-of-work train cleaner accused of executing two transit supervisors in a drunken rage walked out of court free yesterday, acquitted of all charges. When the verdict was read, the man, Darryl Dinkins, 42, sat and held his lawyer's hand, trembling and crying. He had been in jail since Feb. 28, 2004, the day after the transit supervisors were
title: Jurors Acquit Man Accused Of Killing Transit Supervisors

body: ROSENBERG--Asenath. Passed away peacefully at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Ben Rosenberg. Matriarch spanning four generations of loving family. Pioneer and mentor in Jewish and early childhood education at Yeshiva of Flatbush, Board of Jewish Education and Lincoln Square Synagogue. Services Thursday 1:00 P.M. at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBERG, ASENATH

body: Soon after two transit supervisors were found shot dead inside a Coney Island railyard in 2004, the police began building a case against Darryl Dinkins, an out-of-work train cleaner. For the two weeks ending yesterday, transit workers and bereaved relatives have filled half of a courtroom in Downtown Brooklyn, seated behind a prosecutor to watch.
title: Railyard Murder Trial Blurs the Lines Between Prosecution and Defense

body: For decades, the only significant noise at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, New York City's first municipal airfield, which opened in 1931, has been the roar of jet engines heading to Kennedy International Airport. But next month, the sound of athletics is expected in a $38 million sports entertainment complex built by Aviator Sports and Recreation
title: SQUARE FEET; Soon a Home to Flying Pucks and Balls

body: The tip of a crowbar jammed behind the big letter P, and all of a sudden, the place was just ''Pepper & OTTER.'' That never could have worked. Who is going to buy a new car from Pepper and Otter? The name was the one thing that Frank Pepper and Lester Potter seemed to always agree on, as far back as 1946, when they opened the Nash dealership on the
title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; A Car Dealership Defined By Big Dreams and Bigger Letters

body: Two years after a City Council investigation found widespread disparities in prices for prescription drugs at New York pharmacies, significant variations persist despite new rules requiring wider disclosure of retail drug prices, according to a Council report released yesterday. Many consumers had no idea that by going to some pharmacies, they
title: Drug Prices Still Vary Widely Across City, Council Survey Finds

body: A 42-year-old motorcyclist was killed yesterday in Coney Island when he slammed into two parked cars, the police said. The man, Michael Rebuffi, was traveling south on Shell Road about 7 a.m. when he apparently lost control of his Kawasaki near Neptune Avenue, the police said. Both cars he hit were unoccupied, the police said. Mr. Rebuffi, of
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Motorcyclist Killed In Crash

body: ON a recent Tuesday morning, Maria Mackin, a trim 44-year-old real estate agent and mother of three, strode purposefully into the backyard of her home in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and beheld her chickens. There were 28 of them, clucking and pecking and scampering around inside a long chicken run fenced in by wire. Among the flock were two coal-black
title: URBAN TACTICS; In the Land of Co-ops, Coops

body: A 7-year-old Coney Island girl and her father were found shot to death yesterday in the man's apartment after he telephoned the child's mother and threatened to kill the girl, the police said. Details about the shootings, including the motive, remained unclear last night, hours after the police said they received a call from the distraught mother
title: Girl and Father Found Dead After Mother Reports Threat

body: The New York City transit system has been filmed and photographed, drawn and chronicled in hardback and in newsprint. Soon it will be heard. All week, a man with a microphone has walked the subway platforms to collect the clattering of the rivets and the whistling horns, the distortion in the loudspeaker, the hush in the compressor's song and the
title: Finding Real New York Noise For a Miniature Subway Line

body: Several years ago, a fire buff named Micheal Boucher began a project about death. Mr. Boucher wanted to compile a list of every firefighter killed in the line of duty since 1865, the year the paid Fire Department of New York was founded. Mr. Boucher knows the world of firefighters. He is a Fire Department dispatcher, the person who sends
title: Recovering the Fallen Of the Fire Department

body: IN the hallways of the School of American Ballet, overlooking Lincoln Center, aspiring young dancers clustered nervously on a Tuesday morning two weeks ago. Some stretched, using the furniture as makeshift barres. Mothers crouched at their children's feet, pressing their palms down on the tops of the arches to increase the point or guiding their
title: DANCE; Applying for Early Admission (Very Early)

body: To the Editor: According to ''For a Homeless Shelter, a Wary Reception'' (Aug. 20), the Department of Homeless Services is going to be paying $96 a night to rent rooms at a single-room-occupancy hotel that usually charges $338 a month. This raises two questions: Why is the city paying almost 10 times what it would cost me to rent a room? And, if
title: Housing the Homeless At the Market Rate

body: Two brothers, a doctor in Brooklyn and an owner of pharmacies in Brooklyn and Queens, led a conspiracy that defrauded Medicaid of millions of dollars by billing the program for H.I.V. drugs and other medicines that were never given to patients, federal prosecutors say. The United States attorney's office announced the arrest yesterday of the
title: 3 Bilked Medicaid of Millions Using Fake Billings, U.S. Says

body: A Brooklyn teenager died last night after he hit his head while trying to climb a fence in front of a school in Ditmas Park, and the police said he may have been electrocuted. Luis Rivera, 17, of Rugby Road, was found unconscious shortly before 8 p.m. with head injuries in front of Public School 217 near the intersection of Newkirk and Coney Island
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teenager Dies Climbing Fence

author: Sara Gran is the author of the novels ''Dope,'' ''Come Closer'' and ''Saturn's Return to New York.''
body: I HAVE a theory about the F train. I think that people who ride the F train, which stops in the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, and is therefore the train of choice for dozens of writers, editors and publishers, choose their subway reading material very carefully. You rarely see the folks who get off at Seventh Avenue reading anything pocket-sized,
title: Call It Booklyn

body: America's newest Muslims arrive in the afternoon crunch at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Their planes land from Dubai, Casablanca and Karachi. They stand in line, clasping documents. They emerge, sometimes hours later, steering their carts toward a flock of relatives, a stream of cabs, a new life. This was the path for Nur Fatima, a
title: More Muslims Are Coming to U.S. After a Decline in Wake of 9/11

body: A JAB, and then another, and another and another, almost like the riveting of bolts at a construction site. When the jabbing stopped an hour later, the two towers were soaring again from the Manhattan bedrock, their windows forever tinted red by the evening sun, their majesty forever set against a sky's lavender sighs. This is how the World Trade
title: About New York; He Bears the Mark of His Loss Sadly

body: Five years ago, on Sept. 11, 2001, terrorists crashed two airliners into the World Trade Center. Downtown smelled like Coke cans and hair on fire. It was televised live. In New York City, 2,749 people were killed. About eight million remained. Since that day, the numbers have changed. The population grew by more than 134,000 from 2000 to 2005, the
title: Old New Yorkers, Newer Ones, and the Line Etched by Sept. 11

body: It's a long way from Hollywood to Staten Island, but the owners of the New York Yankees are trying to make the stretch. The Yankees, who own a minority share of their minor-league affiliate on Staten Island, are buying out the majority owners, with plans to turn management of the financially underperforming franchise over to a company run by Peter
title: Full Ownership by the Yankees Could Be Just What a Minor-League Team Needs

body: IF P. T. Barnum had hired Breughel or Bosch to paint sideshow banners, they might have resembled the art of Joe Coleman. Obsessively depicting a grim moral universe of transgression and retribution, Mr. Coleman paints grotesque images of murderers and victims, freaks and monsters, disease, depravity and perversities of every kind. In his
title: ART; Grim, Grotesque and Uptown at Last

body: The P.A. system is blaring the theme song to ''Three's Company.'' Children are trailing after a ''king'' outfitted in crimson and crown who has materialized in the stands. Teenagers in the next row are posing for MySpace pictures. Fans, direct your attention to the field. Between the laundry-toss contest and the singalongs, there is a baseball game
title: Last Call for Summer: Three Days Before Real Life Returns; Cyclones vs. Singalongs

body: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the rescue of an elderly woman from a fire in her Brooklyn apartment misstated her address and neighborhood. The address is 1935 Shore Parkway, not Belt Parkway, and it is in Gravesend, not Coney Island.

body: Firefighters rescued an 85-year-old woman from a fire that broke out about 6:40 a.m. yesterday in her apartment in a high-rise building at 1935 Belt Parkway in Coney Island. The firefighters, Brian Pascascio, 24, and Joe Walz, 38, found the woman lying next to her bed and carried her out of the 11th-floor apartment. The woman, whom fire officials
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Firefighters Rescue Woman

body: The city's most neglected neighborhood parks continue to get worse, according to an annual report released by a parks advocacy group yesterday. An analysis by the group, New Yorkers for Parks, found that the 10 small parks it had listed as the city's 10 worst last year also received a failing grade this year. Several parks, among them University
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Report Says Worst Parks Get Worse

body: The Pluot, a cross between a plum and an apricot, looks like a plum. But the first bite of the brilliant red flesh of the new Raspberry Jewel Pluot from California is pure honey. Then a bit of acidity kicks in to give the juicy, mouth-filling richness some balance. Pluots are easy to pit and slice to pave a fruit tart. They are $5.95 a pound at the
title: FOOD STUFF; Cousin of the Apricot, With a Plummy Accent

body: A track fire sent smoke billowing through a subway tunnel in Downtown Brooklyn during the evening rush yesterday, halting two subway trains carrying nearly 4,000 passengers, who had to be led to safety on the Manhattan Bridge. At least 25 people received minor injuries, including 10 passengers and three firefighters who were treated at hospitals
title: Smoky Track Fire Strands Riders On 2 Trains on Manhattan Bridge

body: Joel W. Harnett, a businessman and civic watchdog who finished last in the Democratic primary for mayor of New York City in 1977, but fueled debate by helping to force the release of a federal investigative report on questionable financial manipulations by city leaders, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Phoenix. He was 80. The cause was prostate
title: Joel Harnett, 80, Leader of Watchdog Group

title: FILM; In the Cinema Of the Street Kid, Casting at Ground Level

body: GELFAND--Pauline. Born September 13, 1909, died August 9, 2006. Beloved mother, loyal friend and proud active supporter of Jewish Women International, B'nai Brith and the Anti-Defamation League. She is survived by a daugher, Carol of Manhattan and a son Thomas of Brooklyn. Services Sunday August 13, 11:30am at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Coney Island
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GELFAND, PAULINE

body: BEHIND the tall grass and trees of Calvert Vaux Park in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, hidden from the soccer players on Sundays, is a nautical graveyard. Burned and rotting hulks of abandoned vessels jut from the dirty beach into the silted, sluggish water of Coney Island Creek. The ribs of other ships emerge from the shallows like bones. No one is sure
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; The Ghost Ships of Coney Island Creek

body: A fire yesterday in a concrete shed for electrical equipment at Coney Island's Astroland Amusement Park led to the evacuation of hundreds of people from the section of the park along Surf Avenue, according to police and fire officials. No one was injured, and the park's best-known rides, including the Wonder Wheel and the Cyclone, continued to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fire At Coney Island

body: Aaron Bondaroff is 29, part Puerto Rican, part Jewish, Brooklyn-born and a high-school dropout. His life weaves through the most elusive subcultures of lower Manhattan. A-Ron, as he is also known, is one of those individuals who embodies a scene. ''I'm so downtown,'' Bondaroff is fond of saying, ''I don't go above Delancey.'' Even so, he longs for
title: The Brand Underground

body: A CENTURY ago, William Reynolds had a dream. A 39-year-old state senator and promoter who had developed four neighborhoods in Brooklyn as well as the largest amusement park in Coney Island, he trucked in a herd of elephants to publicize the Riviera of the East, his dream Mediterranean-style city by the sea. There were modern wonders like hot and
title: Our Towns; Oceanfront City With a Past Wonders About Its Present

body: IN provincial Russian cities, the bars and restaurants can be prohibitively expensive. So for most people the only thing to do on a fine summer evening is go for a walk. title: URBAN TACTICS; The Promenade, Soviet Style

body: The Brooklyn Cyclones and the Oneonta Tigers played the longest game in the history of the New York-Penn League yesterday. Oneonta won, 6-1, at the Cyclones' KeySpan Park in Coney Island in a 26-inning game that ran 6 hours 40 minutes. The Pawtucket Red Sox defeated the Rochester Red Wings, 3-2, in 33 innings in 1981 in the longest professional
title: BASEBALL; 6 Hours 40 Minutes: Cyclones Fall to Oneonta in 26 Innings

body: TO reach the beach at Fort Tilden, keep the missile silos on your right, the munitions buildings on your left, and head due south of the cannon batteries. Remember this, because there are no signs to point the way, no scents of sunscreen, lifeguard's whistles nor flying Frisbees; just these military landmarks, the briny breeze and the roar of the
title: MY CITY; To the Battlements, and Take Sunscreen

body: Getting from here to there using the Internet has become almost routine with Web sites like Mapquest and Google maps. Many drivers are also using satellite technology linked to computer mapping systems in their cars to guide them to their destinations. In the New York City area, where public transportation is paramount, Internet maps for subways,

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Is Abducted And Raped

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST BRIGHTON; Chelsea It's Not, But a Borough Can Dream

body: Mendel Mokotoff was born in Manhattan in 1911. During the early 1930's, he owned a butter-and-egg business in Coney Island, according to an old Brooklyn directory. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Genealogists' Lament: Yesteryear Is Gone

body: For 41 years, darkness was upon the face of the parachute jump in Coney Island. The 277-foot tower, shaped like a giant blossom at the end of a tapering stalk, dropped its last screaming rider in 1965 and fell silent. For years it rotted, a skeletal symbol of Coney Island's long decline, narrowly escaping demolition. Last night, the city turned the
title: Flower of a Tower Is Relighted in Coney Island

body: When Josh Hamilton stepped into the batter's box yesterday, three of his Hudson Valley Renegades teammates moved to the top of the dugout steps. Hamilton bent his knees and waggled his bat. His teammates stared as if the World Series were at stake. This, undoubtedly, was an eagerly anticipated plate appearance. Even if it was only batting practice.

body: A century ago, the greatest playground was Coney Island, a pre-Disney seaside place to cavort at the southernmost edge of Brooklyn. Here the sound of the Atlantic surf first gave way to screams from the Cyclone roller coaster in 1927, the hot dog entered the American recreational diet, and freak shows came to be treated as art. It was an amusement
title: The City Life; Where Mermaids Dare to Tread

body: THE McCARREN PARK POOL in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is surely one of the last places in New York you would expect to see a concert. Shuttered by the city 22 years ago, it is a 50,000-square-foot void, its floor specked with decades-old turquoise paint and its walls blanketed by layers of graffiti. It lacks electricity and lights, and its bathrooms have
title: Dive In, the Music's Fine: Rock Moves Outdoors

body: Irving A. Berk, who as founder of the Berk Trade and Business School in New York supervised the training of plumbers, electricians, car mechanics and secretaries for 65 years, died on June 16 at his home in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. title: Irving A. Berk, 100, the Founder Of a Trade and Business School

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | MINOR LEAGUE BASEBALL; Watching the Boys of Summer

title: URBAN STUDIES: Jumping; Their Great Escape

title: Paid Notice: Deaths BERK, IRVING A.

body: Dr. John Newcomer is a psychiatrist who generally treats people with severe ailments of the mind and spirit. title: In Diabetes, One More Burden for the Mentally Ill

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: ON THE WATERFRONT; Turning Rivers Into Playgrounds

title: THE VOICE; When the Horsemen Passed By

body: ''THIS is the Bronx I grew up in,'' I said with a sigh to a friend from Puerto Rico. We were at land's end, at the eastern edge of East Tremont Avenue, the point where the Long Island Sound ends and the East River begins. To the left, the long arch of the Throgs Neck Bridge played tag with the sunlight. My friend and I had driven there from
title: His Island City

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Priestess; Lost and Found

body: The name of the bank has changed, as with most of this block of Jerome Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. body: WHY GO NOW -- New York has never lacked for colorful characters, evocative settings and random experiences, in sum, fiction's fodder. That's why, perhaps more than any other American city, New York has been a beacon to writers and a ready-made backdrop for novels. So much so that it's entirely possible to plan a vacation based solely around
title: GOING TO; Literary New York

body: A Mother's Memory Q. My late mother, who grew up in Yorkville, told me that as a little girl she would take the subway ''all the way downtown'' to get breast milk for her twin baby brothers. body: MY list of dumpling loves is long. It includes tiny Turkish manti, griddle-crisped Japanese gyoza, meaty Korean mandoo, anything Italian -- from diminutive tortellini to hulking ravioli -- and every kind of steamed, boiled or fried Chinese dumplings, swimming in soup or stuffed with it. body: At 76, Hilma Wolitzer cannot afford another 12-year writer's block like the one that ended recently with the publication of ''The Doctor's Daughter,'' her seventh novel. title: A Writer's Characters Are Back; Words Flow

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Found On N Train

Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa, had just helped kill. The man with the secret was

title: John Falotico, Detective Who Arrested Berkowitz, Dies at 82

title: Held in 9/11 Net, Muslims Return To Accuse U.S.

title: Man Found On Q Train; Probably Died Hours Earlier

title: The Neediest Cases; Learning From Youthful Missteps, and Hoping to Teach Others to Avoid Them

title: URBAN TACTICS; A Desire Named Streetcar

author: E-mail: dabarry@nytimes.com
body: THE artistic influences of Marie A. Roberts are many. There is Giotto, with his genius for bringing religious subjects to life. Raphael, with his thorough command of composition. Masoccio. Toulouse-Lautrec. Van Gogh. Lionel the Lion-Faced Man. And don't forget Baron Paucci, the World's Smallest Perfect Man. Or the fake Siamese twins known as the
title: About New York; Pictures Of Exhibitions

author: E-mail: hjaraton@nytimes.com
body: STEPHON MARBURY brought his right-way-to-play-according-to-Brownie A game to Madison Square Garden, just in time to meet the challenge of the amazing Steve Nash, who is on his most valuable player validation tour. Remember the insinuation by some Shaquille O'Neal cheerleaders last spring that the vote for Nash was, in part, a victory for fair skin
title: Sports of The Times; Point Guards, Projections and Paths Taken
